title: How to Make Hiring Less Gender-Biased
sub_head: A behavioral economist answers questions on hiring more women, ruined surprises and party expectations
body:
Behavioral economist Dan Ariely uses psychological research to advise on everyday dilemmas. Read more columns here.
Dear Dan,
My company strives for more gender equality, particularly in leadership positions. To help us achieve this goal we make sure when we examine the top candidates for the position that we anonymize the resumes and have them reviewed by both male and female members of our staff. Still, our recent round of hiring has not resulted in the desired diversity. What else can we do to improve our hiring process? —Pat

Tossing a coin won’t necessarily give you equal numbers of heads and tails in the short run, and the same goes for fair hiring practices. Here, too, you should not expect proportional hiring as an immediate result; you can only look at trends once you have hired a substantial number of people.
